channel.title: Posts - Today I Learnt...
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Today I Learnt...

item.title: ITerm2's "Cursor boost" feature will cause everything to appear dimmed
item.description: I had inadvertently moved the “Cursor Boost” slider to a high level and the terminal became very dim and hard to read.

item.title: `pdbpp` has a useful 'sticky' mode
item.description: pdbpp provides some additional interactive commands to pdb. One such command is sticky which toggles “sticky mode”:

item.title: SystemD timers can be stopped
item.description: Timers are systemd unit files that control services. I didn’t realise until today that, when disabling a timer, it also needs to be stopped too.

item.title: You can use Git log to view the evolution of a function
item.description: Modern versions of git log provide a -L option which lets you trace the evolution of a line range or function:

item.title: To prefer `dateutil` over `pytz`
item.description: When constructing datetime.datetime instances, it’s better to use dateutil to provide the tzinfo argument â€” avoid using pytz.

item.title: Pytest doesn't play nicely with ipdb
item.description: To ensure breakpoint() triggers ipdb as my default debugger, I used to set:

item.title: Chrome has a flags page for enabling experimental features
item.description: Find it at chrome://flags.

item.title: How to use custom functions with `:cdo`
item.description: Vim’s :cdo command lets you run an Ex command in each entry in the quickfix list.

item.title: The order of permissions matters with `chmod`
item.description: As in these two commands behave differently: $ chmod -R g+X,g-wx .

item.title: About Github's `@me` search term
item.description: Which lets you filter by the current user. For example, use is:open is:pr author:@me to show pull-requests authored by yourself:

item.title: Recruiters talk about T-shaped leaders
item.description: For example: The T metaphor indicates expertise in a single field as well as the ability to collaborate across disciplines.

item.title: Virgin Media's "Web Safe" product uses DNS
item.description: Virgin Media’s Web Safe product applies its blocking rules using its DNS servers, the same way the OpenDNS’s Family Shield does.

item.title: How to scroll horizontally with a mouse
item.description: If you hold shift while using the mouse wheel then you can scroll horizontally.

item.title: You can take screenshots with Chrome DevTools
item.description: Chrome DevTools can take screenshots via its Command Menu (which can be opened with cmd + shift + p).

item.title: You can arbitrarily chain Python comparison operations
item.description: Which explains why: >>> False == False in [False] True This odd looking expression is equivalent to (False == False) and (False in [False]), hence why it evaluates to True.

item.title: How to pipe an argument list into Vim
item.description: Use something like: $ echo file1 file2 | xargs -o vim The -o option for xargs re-opens stdin as /dev/tty (rather than the default /dev/null) and is essential otherwise Vim will break your terminal when it exits.

item.title: How to copy the current filepath to the system clipboard in Vim
item.description: Run: :let @* = expand("%")where @* references the system clipboard register.

item.title: How to search for fixed strings with `grep` and `ripgrep`
item.description: To search for a fixed string (i.e. not a regex), use:

item.title: How to easily disable a CircleCI workflow
item.description: Sometimes it’s useful to only run a subset of CircleCI jobs after each commit to a pull request branch.

item.title: BBC Sounds only works on Alexa if the language setting is UK English
item.description: Was puzzled as to why: alexa, play bbc radio four

item.title: How temporary files are removed on MacOS
item.description: On MacOS, temporary files are stored in either /tmp/ or a per-user temporary folder specified by the $TMPDIR environment variable; this is normally a subfolder of /var/folders/.

item.title: You can define custom file-type filters in `ripgrep`
item.description: ripgrep lets you filter files by their language type â€” e.

item.title: How to enable Docker BuildKit in MacOS Docker Desktop
item.description: Since Docker 18.09, you can the BuildKit feature to take advantages of improved performance and extra features when building images â€” see Build images with Buildkit from the Docker docs.

item.title: You can specify the file-type for `bat`
item.description: bat is a useful replacement for cat that supports syntax highlighting.

item.title: About `envsubst`
item.description: Am learning Kubernetes and was looking for ways to dynamically create YAML resource files.

item.title: How to add project-specific Vim settings
item.description: There’s various ways to do this but I quite like using an autocmd based on a buffer’s filepath.

item.title: You can stack `pytest`'s `parametrize` decorators
item.description: As in: import pytest @pytest.mark.parametrize("x", [1,2,3]) @pytest.mark.parametrize("y", [4,5,6]) def test_cartesian_product(x, y): pass which will run the test for all combinations of the two input lists:

item.title: About YAML's node anchors and aliases
item.description: I’ve seen these a few times but only today decided to actually work out how they worked.

item.title: You can label parameterized fixtures with pytest
item.description: For example, running this parameterized test: @pytest.mark.parametrize( "date", ( datetime.

item.title: Universal Ctags can index more things than I realised
item.description: For instance, it can index make, markdown and ini files without custom configuration.

item.title: A better way of configuring `mypy`
item.description: I didn’t realise you can put all your config into setup.

item.title: How to spell-check markdown repos on CircleCI
item.description: The tmaier/markdown-spellcheck Docker image wraps node-markdown-spellcheck and can be used locally and on CircleCI to spell-check markdown files.

item.title: How to set per-project `ripgrep` and `fzf` exclude rules
item.description: In some projects, you want ripgrep to ignore some files that aren’t in .

item.title: Vim-markdown has some useful commands
item.description: I use sheerun/vim-polyglot but disable its markdown support in favour of plasticboy/vim-markdown.

item.title: GSuite's "Groups Admin" role can read any group email
item.description: If members of your Google org want to administer groups, it’s tempting to make them a “Groups Admin”.

item.title: How to run Jekyll in a Docker container
item.description: To run the server, run: docker run --rm \ --volume="${PWD}:/srv/jekyll" \ -p 4000:4000 \ -it jekyll/jekyll:3.

item.title: About how to use `keywordprg` effectively
item.description: Hitting K in Vim opens the program specified by keywordprg, passing the keyword under the cursor as an argument â€” effectively executing this:

item.title: How to configure `ctags` to parse Terraform files
item.description: If you’re using Universal Ctags (which you should be), you just need to add a ~/.

item.title: You can easily share 1Password items via a link
item.description: People often ask about where certain credentials are in 1Password and I’ve only just discovered each item has a link that can be shared.

item.title: You can convert a Slack group direct message chat into a private channel
item.description: See https://slack.com/intl/en-gb/help/articles/217555437-Move-group-direct-messages-to-a-private-channel

item.title: How to use Bandit with Vim's quickfix list
item.description: One way to populate Vim’s quickfix list is by running :make which runs the program specified by the makeprg setting.

item.title: Exuberant-ctags has been superceded by Universal-ctags
item.description: In the sense that the Exuberant ctags project has stalled, and Universal ctags has been introduced to continue development.

item.title: About `column`
item.description: Which formats input into columns. This is useful for formatting data into a table structure.

item.title: You can hide night-time hours in Google calendar
item.description: In the “Week” view of Google Calendar, it’s annoying that each day is listed from 00:00 onwards.

item.title: You can run `:grep` without using parent shell process
item.description: Using ripgrep as a :grep command can be configured with:

item.title: There's a `QuickFixCmdPost` event in Vim
item.description: Which you can target in an autocmd to open the quickfix window whenever a quickfix command populates the error list (e.

item.title: You can jump to previous quickfix lists in Vim
item.description: Vim remembers the previous ten quickfix lists; you can list them with:

item.title: How to embed markdown content in a Github code block
item.description: Normally, fenced code blocks are delimited with triple backticks ```.

item.title: You can create QR codes for WiFi networks
item.description: Create a QR code for your network at https://qifi.

item.title: `fd` has an option for searching filepaths
item.description: If you pass -p, then the fd will retrieve all filepaths matching $PATTERN:

item.title: `datetime.datetime` is a subclass of `datetime.date`
item.description: See for yourself: >>> import datetime >>> isinstance(datetime.datetime.now(), datetime.

item.title: The keyboard shortcut for grabbing a MFA code in 1PW
item.description: After opening the 1Password mini window (with cmd + option + \), select the item you want and hit shift + ctrl + cmd + c to copy the MFA code to your clipboard.

item.title: How to use AWS profiles that require MFA
item.description: If you have an AWS organisation and several child AWS accounts that you can assume-role into, you can work around MFA restrictions on the trust relationship using a mfa_serial setting in ~/.

item.title: About the difference between minimising and hiding windows in MacOS
item.description: Minimising: âŒ˜ + m minimises the active application window.

item.title: About `readonly` Bash variables
item.description: Doing this: $ readonly myvar=1 means that $myvar can’t have its value changed within the global scope.

item.title: About `shellcheck`
item.description: Which is a static analysis tool for shell scripts.

item.title: About `pip-licenses`
item.description: Which is a useful Python library that lists all the licenses of packages installed with pip:

item.title: About Bash's DEBUG signal
item.description: Bash has a DEBUG signal that you can register a handler for using trap.

item.title: How to resolve Git rebase conflicts on renamed files
item.description: If there’s been a large-scale renaming of files in master and you attempt to rebase your pull-request branch, the resulting conflicts can be tricky to resolve.

item.title: There is a "Bongcloud" chess opening
item.description: Which starts 1 f3 and 2 Kf2. Played by Magnus Carlsen recently: https://www.

item.title: How to use `xargs` with `printf`
item.description: This is obvious in retrospect but it hadn’t dawned on me that you can use xargs printf to use STDIN as printf arguments.

item.title: AWS ASGs have an 'instance refresh' feature
item.description: Which lets you replace all the instances in an auto-scaling group, possibly with a new AMI.

item.title: The MacOS keybinds for en- and em-dashes
item.description: Which are: alt + - for an en-dash (â€“); shift + alt + - for an em-dash (â€”); You can always get them from the ctrl + cmd + space character picker but good to know quicker alternatives.

item.title: How to read from one buffer to another in Vim
item.description: Refer to the buffer’s number using a hash. For example, run:

item.title: SSH config supports multiple host patterns in one block
item.description: From man ssh_config: Host Restricts the following declarations (up to the next Host or Match keyword) to be only for those hosts that match one of the patterns given after the keyword.

item.title: There's a Chrome extension for switching AWS IAM roles
item.description: It’s the AWS Extend Switch Roles extension. AWS’s Console only keeps your 5 most recent AWS accounts as quick links, which this extension gives doesn’t limit you.

item.title: YAML has several string-parsing gotchas
item.description: For instance, in YAML 1.1: Yes and No parse to true and false x:y is parsed as a base-60 number if y is less than 60 See for yourself with these Python tests:

item.title: Javascript's unary `+` operator casts `null` to zero
item.description: As in: > +null 0 which is different from parseInt or parseFloat which return NaN when given null.

item.title: How to count lines of code in a Git repo for a given commit
item.description: For a given commit $SHA, use: $ git diff --shortstat `git hash-object -t tree /dev/null`.

item.title: About Vim's `:helpgrep` command
item.description: Which lets you search Vim’s help files for a given pattern.

item.title: Vim recommends using Emacs-style key bindings in command mode
item.description: As in, using these command-mode maps: " start of line :cnoremap <C-A> <Home> " back one character :cnoremap <C-B> <Left> " delete character under cursor :cnoremap <C-D> <Del> " end of line :cnoremap <C-E> <End> " forward one character :cnoremap <C-F> <Right> " recall newer command-line :cnoremap <C-N> <Down> " recall previous (older) command-line :cnoremap <C-P> <Up> " back one word :cnoremap <Esc><C-B> <S-Left> " forward one word :cnoremap <Esc><C-F> <S-Right> See http://vimdoc.

item.title: How to conditionally include items in a Terraform list
item.description: It’s not obvious how to build a Terraform list where an item is only included if some condition is met.

item.title: You can change the font in Slack with `/slackfont $font`
item.description: For example: /slackfont Comic Sans MS or even /slackfont Wingdings.

item.title: You can display the typed text in Alfred in a huge typeface
item.description: By pressing cmd + L after typing the text.

item.title: Python 3.7 supports postponed evaluation of annotations
item.description: For example, instead of: import _csv def generate_report(writer: '_csv.

item.title: Vim doesn't create the persistent undo folder automatically
item.description: I have this in ~/.vimrc: " Keep undo history between sessionsif has('persistent_undo') set undofile set undodir=~/.

item.title: How to use type annotations with Python's `csv` module
item.description: Adding a type annotation for a “writer” object created by csv.

item.title: How to configure Alfred's Bear workflow to open notes in the main window
item.description: This applies to the Bear workflow written in Go whose default behaviour (in v1.

item.title: About better YAML file folding in Vim
item.description: Using foldmethod=indent is ok but it’s better to use the pedrohdz/vim-yaml-folds plugin.

item.title: OpenDNS provide free porn-blocking DNS servers
item.description: Installation requires switching the DNS servers of your router or device to use the OpenDNS ones.

item.title: AWS Availability Zones have counter-intuitive IDs
item.description: Today, the AWS Service Health Dashboard referred to an Availability Zone in a way I wasn’t familiar with:

item.title: You can rate-limit issues using a Sentry DSN
item.description: If you want to manage how your event quota is consumed with Sentry, you can apply rate limits at the DSN level.

item.title: How to list pages with matching tag in Hugo
item.description: In a detail template, you can grab a post’s tags with {{ .

item.title: About `:help macvim`
item.description: MacVim ships with its own help files, accessed via:

item.title: About Vim's `:diffthis` command
item.description: You can manually compare two more open buffers by running:

item.title: About the stationery pad feature in Finder
item.description: If you use Finder to mark a file as a “stationery pad” then apps will open a copy of the file.

item.title: About `pngcrush`
item.description: It’s an image optimizer for PNG files. It’s available via Homebrew for MacOS and works like:

item.title: Asana has some magic search terms
item.description: If you use the “Search this project” widget (via the “…” link on the right-hand side of the project view), you can search for:

item.title: You can have SASS asset pipelines in Hugo
item.description: Which lets you build a CSS stylesheet via something like:

item.title: About text fragments
item.description: Modern versions of Chrome and Edge support Text Fragments, which let you specify a text snippet in the URL fragment that the browser can highlight (or bring to the user’s attention in another way).

item.title: Renaming a Terraform module is dangerous
item.description: As the state file uses the module name in identifiers and so a module rename causes Terraform to think all existing resources need to be destroyed and recreated.

item.title: Where authentication for the `ubuntu` user on a EC2 instance is defined
item.description: The file that controls where the default ubuntu user on an Ubuntu EC2 instance is /etc/sudoers.

item.title: About the phrase "Parking downhill"
item.description: From https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=23118940 Before putting a project or incomplete task away, make notes of what the next thing was that you were going to work on.

item.title: About Alfred's clipboard history feature
item.description: Alfred has a clipboard history feature which lets you easily pluck out previous values from your system clipboard.

item.title: About Alfred's snippet collections
item.description: You can create “collections” of snippets in Alfred, such as:

item.title: About Quitter
item.description: There’s a MacOS app called Quitter which will automatically quit applications after some period of inactivity.

item.title: About the MacOS `screencapture` utility
item.description: It’s what MacOS uses for its shortcuts but can be called from the command-line:

item.title: About Twitter's `min_faves` search filter
item.description: You can do searches like: from:frankieboyle min_faves:10000 to see, for example, the best tweets from a given account.
